 God rightly saw fit to judge them publically in order to make an example to the very young church that He is there and He sees all that is taking place. Arch, but God DIDN'T judge them publically.
 They were before church leader(s) and a unnumberd group of 'young' men individually when they individually died.

 In ANY other situation, this event would be circumspect.

Jo, speaking as one who has a high regard for your intellect and integrity I find this a sad cop-out. Ananias and his wife may not have been moral paragons; they lied about having given everything to the church, and that is morally weak and culpable. But is it a capital crime? It seems to me that what the Holy Spirit chooses to do is absolutely your concern, if you are to give its actions your unconditional imprimatur.

 
 Why? God allows people to die all the time for NO apparent reason, so why should we be surprised at this? This gets to the issue, IMO, that the standards God is held to are not the same standards we are held to. For people to kill someone for lying would be too much, yes. But think about it ... if God is real (and it is my understand you don't believe that, but for the sake of this let's go along with it if anything because this is the way many religious people think), then obviously he's not bound to our standards of morality--people in the world die all the time, seemingly needlessly. It's not like we could stop the Holy Spirit, so why be concerned? Operating under the understanding that God is real, what's the point of concerning oneself with the fact God would kill someone? It's not like we could change that.

 Yes, and this is why I would never submit to God were He proven to exist. Any leader, be they Prime Minister, President or Supreme Omnipotent Being must be held to some standards. To demand dictate laws and then happily break them because 'He's the boss' is nothing short of tyranny. Nobody deserves respect or obedience who displays such hypocrisy.
 
 As to the original question, most certainly not. The Bible is contradictory and prejudiced. A society modelled on it in it's entirety is one that is barbaric, bigoted and bloody. That is of course not to say that it doesn't have some part in our society. As much as I disagree with much of it, I do also admit it has some very good elements; and, coming form a Christian society, concede that much of what I hold as good and great in my society owes a lot to the Bible. So in short, yes I believe it has a part to play in our society, but certainly should never be held as the only and unquestionable basis.
